newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Jan 13.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Jan 13.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Monday's edition of The Wall Street Journal:
- Tyco International proposed acquiring American Standard for $50 a share or about $4 billion, plus assumed debt.
- Raytheon appeared to be leading Northrop in the battle to acquire the defense assets of GM's Hughes Electronics for about $9.5 billion.
- American Airlines warned that the prospects of a strike "are very real" after the National Mediation Board declared an impasse in talks between the carrier and its pilots' union.
- The 11 percent plunge in Japan's stock market last week does not appear the threaten markets elsewhere.
- The economy added 262,000 jobs in December and stocks and bonds fell on the news.
- FoxMeyer Health sued drug distributor McKesson and a dozen manufacturers accusing them of conspiring to ruin its drug-wholesale business.
- ABC's nightly newscast lost the number one slot four of the past five weeks to NBC, a first sign of weakness at the top network newscast since 1989.
- Plaintiffs' lawyers in the Texaco racial discrimination case are seeking $29 million in fees.
- Odyssey Partners plans to dissolve because the $3 billion fund has grown too bulky to easily invest.
- Amgen and Regeneron said their Lou Gehrig's drug had failed to help patients in a trial.
- Two big holders in DFS filed suit to block the $2.47 billion sale of a controlling interest in the duty-free retailer to LVMH.
- Mercury Finance agreed to acquire Bank of Boston 's Fidelity Acceptance consumer-finance unit for stock currently valued at $453.8 million.
- H.J. Heinz said the head of Weight Watchers resigned.

- Many of the gains over the past year in stock market indexes were generated by a small group of stocks with gargantuan market values, whose performance overshadowed more ordinary returns of the majority of issues.
